description: From Latin conglomerātus, past participle of conglomerāre (“to pile into a heap, to roll together”), from con- (“prefix indicating a being or bringing together of several objects”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ḱóm (“beside, by, near, with”)) + glomerāre (from glomerō (“to pile into a heap, to make into a ball, glomerate”), from glomus (“ball of thread; ball-shaped mass”), from Proto-Indo-European *gel- (“to form into a ball; ball”)).

adjectives.description: conglomerate (comparative more conglomerate, superlative most conglomerate)

entries.meaning: (geology) Composed of fragments of rock, pebbles, or stones cemented together.
(business) A corporation formed by the combination of several smaller corporations whose activities are unrelated to the corporation's primary activity.
(geology) A rock consisting of gravel or pebbles embedded in a matrix.

verbs.description: conglomerate (third-person singular simple present conglomerates, present participle conglomerating, simple past and past participle conglomerated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To combine together into a larger mass.
(transitive, business) To combine together into a larger corporation.
